lg.l: Beautiful Longwood, Longwood. A sheep station estate and formal gardens established in Featherston, in the south of New Zealand’s North Island, in the 1850s. lying far away
‘Neath the green shade of ever verdant trees;
Bathed in the scent of flowers which on the breeze
Comes wafting upwards, in the blush of day.
Cypress and stately pine Stately pine. Possibly a reference to indigenous tōtara trees that were preserved in the estate gardens. are mingled there,
With the fair weeping willow in between,
Whose graceful form and dress of tender green,
Blend in sweet contrast with the flow’rets fair.
Bright glowing flowers inlay the velvet lawn,
Like rich mosaic on tesselated floor,
And round each casement and the open door
They twine and garland in fantastic form.
Vistas of hills peep out amid the trees,
Making a landscape more than passing fair—
The drone of bees upon the stilly air
Floats like a heavenly whisper on the breeze.
Groups of sweet children gambol on the grass,
Children with great brown eyes and flaxen hair
Waving about their laughing faces fair—
A fairy band who greet you as you pass.
Beautiful Longwood, in thy quiet nooks
How have I dreamed out hours in soft repose,
Feeling that earth contained no web of woes,
While reading Nature from her own bright books.
Shadow of holy peace still softly rest
On Longwood’s beauty, on its inmates dear;
Shadow of God’s great blessing keep them here
In perfect peace, in faith, thy children blest.
